relatedanime.anime: NG Knight Ramune & 40 DX: Wakuwaku Jikuu - Honoo no Daisousasen

anime.description: VS Knight Lamune & 40 Fire is the "next generation" of the Lamune series. Baba Lamunade is followed home by two strange peddler girls who give him a CD-rom game. After he beats "The Legend of Lamuness", the girls come out of his computer and bring him to DokiDoki Space. He is the third descendant of the hero Lamuness who must stop Don Genosai from resurrecting the great evil Abraham. Accompanied by PQ, his advisor robot, and the two Lamuness no miko - Parfait and Cacao - he must pilot the Kaizer Fire mecha. However, he needs another pilot, and Da Cider is the only man for the job! Together they search for the gates to the different zones of DokiDoki Space and encounter other friends and enemies. Why is Lamunade having flashbacks? And just who the heck are those two in those goofy costumes?? VS Knight Lamune & 40 Fire is a television series that also spawned an OVA series (Fresh) that was released as Knights of Ramune. There is also a manga series and some novels.

tag.name: maintenance tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: perverted
tag.description: Is a concept describing those types of human behavior that are excessive or deviated from what is considered to be orthodox or normal.

tag.name: android
tag.description: An android is a robot or synthetic organism designed to look and act like a human.

tag.name: robot
tag.description: A robot is an automatically guided machine, able to do tasks on its own. Another common characteristic is that by its appearance or movements, a robot often conveys a sense that it has intent or agency of its own. Not to be confused with android (human-like robot).

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: calling your attacks
tag.description: "GIGAAAAAA DRIIIIIILLL BREAKEEEEEERRR" If you can do something more impressive than just throw a punch, your attack(s) must have an equally impressive name. More than that, you have to call it out as you launch the attack. It doesn`t matter if it`s a martial arts move, a magical spell or your secret superweapon, if you can`t say its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Having a special attack is always a must, but not impressive enough. Every special attack needs a name. A really awesome and outstanding name which is easy to remember and even easier and impressive to yell. Because it just is not enough to name your attack. No, to unleash the full power of your attack, you have to call its name in your most MANLY and LOUDEST voice. It does not matter whether it is a martial arts move, a magical spell or flying drills from your mecha, if you can`t call its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Not a requirement but wearing shades while calling your attack makes it at least twice as cool, moreover giving your mecha or magical companion shades too results in an immeasurable level of awesomeness, bringing down every enemy just through the POWER OF YOUR VOICE. A standard feature of practically every mecha, mahou shoujo, high fantasy, or martial arts anime. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: time travel
tag.description: In time travel anime characters are transported through time either figuratively or literally to find themselves either in the past or the future

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: piloted robot
tag.description: Piloted Robots are, as the name suggests, robots that cannot control themselves; they need to be steered from somewhere, this can be from a human sitting inside or a remote controlled option.

tag.name: slapstick
tag.description: Slapstick humour is generally recognized by lots of physical abuse, horseplay and practical jokes. Also often seen are impossible situations, using sounds to illustrate impossible stunts that aren`t shown on-screen and to create tension for audience anticipation.

tag.name: parody
tag.description: Anime that imitate other stories (can be from TV, film, books, historical events, ...) for comic effect by exaggerating the style and changing the content of the original. Also known as spoofs. It can also refer to when whole elements of one work are lifted out of their context and reused.

tag.name: new
tag.description: Not based on anything, the story is a new work, usually made up by the people involved in creating the anime. Generally if an original work (原作) credit is given, it will be to the studio, or director, or other members of the production team.

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: ecchi
tag.description: Fan service is found in many anime, in many forms. When the service has a distinctly sexual slant to it, and it appears to be a major focus of the show, then it`s safe to assume you`re watching ecchi. The word "ecchi" is used by English-speaking anime fans to refer to refer to soft-core pornographic or sexually suggestive anime and manga. This is a western invention; in Japanese, it is a catch-all term for all things anyhow sexual in nature, not being limited to porn, but also not really considered a "milder" term, as it may also refer to sexual intercourse itself. The term "ecchi" in Japanese comes from the pronunciation of the letter "H" in English, which is rendered into Japanese syllabary as エッチ, which in turn is transliterated in the English alphabet as "ecchi" or "etchi". It is not, as many believe, short for "hentai" -- that, too, seems to be a western invention. It is, however, nearly as misunderstood and misapplied a term as "hentai". The line between ecchi and hentai, from the western perspective over these terms, can be hard to draw at times; one good rule of thumb is: if it was aired on Japanese public TV at all, it probably wasn`t hentai. Ecchi usually features all the specifics to human anatomy that can only be found in anime, and generally avoids full nudity, instead abusing of panty shots. Hentai, on the other hand, will usually show full frontal nudity in some explicit form, including genitalia, and full, intimate sex scenes. At its mildest, ecchi is composed of double entendres, big misunderstandings, and sexual farce; at its most explicit, it is still in the realm of softcore pornography, with full breast shots, full back nudity and similar content, but no display of genitalia. Another good way to distinguish the two is looking for animated sex scenes; if one is found, you have generally left the genre entirely, though a few borderline exceptions apply here. For AniDB`s purposes, the distinction between explicit ecchi and actual hentai is simple: if it was sold with a 18+ restriction in its country of origin, it is hentai; if it was sold without it, it is ecchi. Source: TV Tropes

tag.name: anthropomorphism
tag.description: Anthropomorphism is the attribution of uniquely human characteristics to non-human beings, inanimate objects, or natural or supernatural phenomena. If it`s an animal or an object (AI excluded) and it speaks and/or does other human-like things (dresses up) then we`re dealing with anthropomorphism. Anthropomorphism leans more on the animal-looking side when compared to http://anidb.net/t7 [juujin], which leans more on the human-looking side.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: wordplay
tag.description: The characters play with words. E.g. purposely or accidentally use similar-sounding but wrongly applied words in the Japanese original, leading to supposedly funny misunderstandings and confusion.

tag.name: reincarnation
tag.description: One of the main characters was reborn in another body.

tag.name: body takeover
tag.description: A person`s body is taken over by some foreign intelligence. It`s not brainwashing, because they still have control of their own mind — but that`s all they have. Either they`ve been reduced to a spectator in their own body, or their soul has been booted out of their body entirely. Either way, the rest of the cast will soon find he`s not himself.

tag.name: body exchange
tag.description: Two or more characters swap bodies (or, equally, swap minds). When this plot is done, usually the voices also switch as narrative cheat to help viewers keep track of who`s who. More subtly, it`s just the eyes. More serious/action-oriented shows might not do this. The Flip often involves characters of different ages, genders, races, or social classes. Another variation is a protagonist and antagonist switching, which usually involves each trying to undermine the other`s organization while simultaneously trying to switch back. If one or both of the characters have superpowers or other special abilities, they`ll have a lot of trouble figuring their new powers out.

tag.name: daikaijuu
tag.description: Literally translating to giant monster, daikaiju is an element found often in Japanese entertainment. Although usually for the science fiction genre it is also often used in horror, fantasy, mecha, and to a lesser extent comedy. Any monster that towers over a house technically qualifies as a daikaiju. Some anime, usually mecha, will go as far as calling their daikaiju with a specific title.

tag.name: monster of the week
tag.description: On a pretty much regular basis — weekly or episodic — the protagonists engage in some kind of conflict. This can be an actual showdown between mecha, or the all-out fight against an enemy, or a (car) race that needs to be won. This can make the anime quite repetitive.

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO CHARACTER
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to character tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what characters they should be assigned to.

tag.name: body and host
tag.description: When a foreign entity like that of a symbiote, body snatcher, puppeteer parasite, or even a hacker (when regarding machines like robots and computers) enters/outright hijacks a body, the possessed subject becomes what is usually called: the host. The basic purpose of the host varies on what the point was for it to have been hijacked in the first place. Sometimes it`s used as a disguise, other times it`s used as a decoy and destraction, even simply being used as a weapon and piece of armor that the possessor uses to cause sheer chaos and destruction, but sometimes... a host can be used for fetish fuel.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

episode.title: 勇者ふたたび!!
Brave Revives!!
Yuusha Futatabi!!
episode.summary: Lamunade beats a mysterious video game he bought cheap, which reveals he is the newest incarnation of the legendary hero Lamuness who saved Dokidoki Space 5,000 years ago. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ギモン!! 勇者の条件
Doubt!! Condition of the Brave
episode.summary: While looking for an Ottama Gate so they can get to the next zone, the team takes a break at a hot spring. After relaxing and more searching they are assisted by mysterious, but familiar, masked heroes Akakaze & Momokaze during a battle. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 氷の伝説
The Legend of the Ice
episode.summary: Separated from his friends while exploring the frozen Anan Zone in search of the final Spirit Knight, Lamuness discovers Drum, a young girl who says she`s been waiting for him for a long time. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 遥かなる誓い
The Promise of Long Ago.
episode.summary: Organ Symphony has told Lamuness it`s time for him to learn everything about the history of Lamuness; how it began, the secrets, and what he needs to do next. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 敵の名はブラックラムネス!!
The Enemy`s Name is Black Lamuness!!
episode.summary: Abram has returned in the body of the original Lamuness, and the battle against the new Black Lamuness begins! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ときめきのパフェ
Beat Fast Parfait.
episode.summary: Transporting to what should be the final VS Field stage to face Black Lamuness, Lamuness finds himself dressed in a uniform, late for school, and in the middle of a love comedy? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 時を越えた恋!!
The Love Over Time!!
episode.summary: The others get jealous as Drum, Cello, and Trumpet fawn over Lamuness, but Cacao remembers the tablet that seemed to refer to the three android girls being the key to finding Water Baron, the final Spirit Knight. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ダンディ特攻!!
Kamikaze Dandy!!
episode.summary: Lamuness returns with the Sword of Lamuness and the knowledge of how to defeat Abram, but before he can make up his mind on what to do, Dandy challenges him to one more fight. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: あばかれた悪夢
Nightmare is Solved
episode.summary: A psychological attack pushes Lamuness into his own mind where he is forced to deal with old emotional scars, but what will Parfait and Cacao find when they enter his mind to help? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 伝説の勇者現る
The legendary Brave appears
episode.summary: After a timely escape, Lamuness has to work together with hero Da Cider to control the mecha Spirit Knight, Kaiser Fire, which needs two pilots. And what`s this about finding two more Spirit Knights? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 幻の少女
The Illusion Girl
episode.summary: Black Lamuness has banished Lamuness` spirit to be unstuck in time, and the phantom of a mysterious girl seems to be dragging him along, showing him important moments with the other Lamuness`. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 幻惑のゲート
Phantom Gate
episode.summary: After wandering to find an Ottama Gate, the team stumbles across dozens of fakes. Will they be able to find the real one, not to mention avoid whatever dangers are hiding behind the fakes? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 愛と悲しみと友情と
Love, Tears, and Friendship...
episode.summary: Abram begins the final battle, and Lamuness decides he won`t sacrifice anyone to win. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: カカオの涙
Cacao`s tears
episode.summary: Having escaped from a maze after being seperated from the others, Lamuness and Cacao end up on a deserted island. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 伝説の終焉
The End of the Legend.
Densetsu no Shuuen
episode.summary: Destroying the body of Black Lamuness has revealed the true form of Abram. One way or another, it is the end of the legend. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: VSフィールドへ!!
Go to the VS Field !!
VS Field e!!
episode.summary: Black Lamuness has trapped the heroes in his VS Field and old enemies granted new strength block Lamuness from continuing on. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ストーンパニック
Stone Panic
Stone Panic
episode.summary: In a VS Field stage where everything is made of stone, Lamuness will have to battle rock warriors, avoid rolling boulders, and stand even boulder puns from Da Cider. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 決戦, 次元城!!
Decisive Battle in the Dimensional Castle!!
episode.summary: Finally arriving at Dimension Castle, everyone rushes in aboard Kaiser Fire to stop Don Genoci from reviving Abram, but things aren`t as they seem. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: とまどいの勇者
The Brave`s Perplexed
episode.summary: Arriving in Harahara Zone, the home of the hero, Lamuness and Da Cider expect a warm welcome, but instead find that everyone wants to be the end of them. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: キケンな勇者鍋
Dangerous Cook-up Brave
episode.summary: Everyone gets separated shortly after arriving in the Gaogao Zone and they all end up with their own problems, but Lamuness better solve his quickly before he becomes stew for an entire village. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 愛のメモリー
Memory of Love
episode.summary: After a sacrifice to save Lamuness, things begin to move quickly on all sides as Don Genoci sends Dandy and Lip to finish Lamuness. But was it a final sacrifice? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ハラペコ王子様
Hungry Prince
episode.summary: Lamuness and friends save someone from hunger who they later find out is the ruler of the Gaogao Zone, Prince Mito. During a losing battle, the prince returns to help his new friends. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 神霊騎士激突!?
Confrontation of the God Knights!?
episode.summary: Narcissist Dandy and Pheromone Lip put Don Genoci`s newest plan into motion by lying to both Lamuness and Mito to try and set them against each other. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: わたしは誰!?
Who am I!?
episode.summary: A crimson fog causes everyone to swap bodies. The fog continues to swap everyone around, but will they be able to end up where they started? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 勇者様は3歳児!?
The Brave is a 3 Year-Old!?
Yuusha-sama wa 3 Sai Ko!?
episode.summary: After everyone else is turned into little kids, Cacao has to safely lead them through an amusement park that is no magical castle. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 対決, 勇者スゴロク!?
Confrontation, Brave`s Monopoly!?
episode.summary: The newest VS Field has Lamuness and Da Cider playing a board game of death where failure means game over for Parfait and Cacao! Source: crunchyroll
